knowledge_graph.title: General ledger
knowledge_graph.description: In bookkeeping, a general ledger is a bookkeeping ledger in which accounting data are posted from journals and aggregated from subledgers, such as accounts payable, accounts receivable, cash management, fixed assets, purchasing and projects. A general ledger may be maintained on paper, on a computer, or in the cloud.

related_questions.question: What is the general ledger in accounting?
related_questions.snippet: A general ledger is a record of all of a company's, and its subsidiaries', assets, liabilities, expenses, income, and equities. General ledgers are generally broken down into records of accounts and account balances and financial transactions and from there, if necessary, into subledgers.
related_questions.title: General Ledger Defined: What It Is & Why You Need One

related_questions.question: What is GL in simple words?
related_questions.snippet: A general ledger, or GL, is a record of your company's financial transactions, summarizing all accounts in one place. It's a good idea to use general ledger software to manage the data as it can be quite complex to do so manually.
related_questions.title: What is a General Ledger in Accounting? | Sage Advice US

related_questions.question: What is an example of a GL account?
related_questions.snippet: Examples of General Ledger Accounts asset accounts such as Cash, Accounts Receivable, Inventory, Investments, Land, and Equipment.
related_questions.title: What is a general ledger account? | AccountingCoach

related_questions.question: What is the difference between bookkeeping and general ledger?
related_questions.snippet: The bookkeeper typically places the account title at the top of the "T" and records debit entries on the left side and credit entries on the right. The general ledger sometimes displays additional columns for particulars, such as transaction description, date, and serial number.
related_questions.title: General Ledger vs. General Journal: What's the Difference? - Investopedia

text_blocks.snippet: General ledger accounting is the process of recording and categorizing all financial transactions of a business in a centralized record called the general ledger. This ledger serves as the foundation for creating financial statements like the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement. It provides a comprehensive view of a company's financial position by tracking assets, liabilities, equity, revenue, and expenses.
Key aspects of general ledger accounting:

list.title: Centralized Record:
list.snippet: The general ledger acts as the master record for all financial transactions, ensuring all data is in one place.

list.title: Double-Entry Accounting:
list.snippet: General ledger accounting relies on the double-entry system, where each transaction affects at least two accounts, with a debit and a credit of equal value.

list.title: Chart of Accounts:
list.snippet: A chart of accounts lists all the general ledger accounts used by a business, categorized by asset, liability, equity, revenue, and expense.

list.title: Transaction Tracking:
list.snippet: The general ledger tracks every financial transaction, providing detailed information about how a business's finances are managed.

list.title: Financial Statement Preparation:
list.snippet: The information in the general ledger is used to prepare essential financial statements that provide insights into a company's financial health.

list.title: Financial Statement Preparation:
list.snippet: The primary purpose is to provide the data needed to create accurate and reliable financial statements.

list.title: Financial Analysis:
list.snippet: It enables businesses to analyze their financial performance and make informed decisions.

list.title: Compliance:
list.snippet: It ensures that businesses comply with accounting standards and regulations.

list.title: Fraud Prevention:
list.snippet: It helps in detecting and preventing accounting errors and fraud by maintaining a clear audit trail.
